‘Twas noontide of summer, the meadow asleep,
A silence so golden, the willows could weep.
The dragonflies shimmered, their wings catching sun,
Tracing bright arabesques where the river did run.

No shadow was cast, save for birds on the wing—
Even time seemed to hush, not daring to sing.
The hay in the fields bowed its head to the light,
And wild roses blushed at the world’s pure delight.

In that warm, endless hush, the heart could recall
The laughter of children, the grasshopper’s call.
But day drifts away as all summers must do,
Leaving memory’s fragrance, as sweet as the dew.
